result.execSummary:
The defendant Mycal R Nealy was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Burglary-Building or Dwelling [Modifiers: Repeater], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).
  • Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: prison term on probation revocation.

superMiscConds.notes: Fines, costs, and restitution are due during term of supervision.  Court further orders 25% of prison wages to be applied toward Court-ordered financial obligations.  If defendant is released with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment enforceable by all creditors' remedies shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.

-Defendant may not enter any school property without prior approval of the agent.
-Submit DNA sample and pay surcharge.
-Pay supervision fees.

Restitution to be paid before court costs. The restitution amount listed reflects an additional Administrative Cost of 10% of the amount of restitution pursuant to Section 973.06(1)(g).  The 5% Restitution Surcharge is equal to 5% of the total of the restitution, costs, attorney fees, and fines, pursuant to Section 973.20(11)(a).   Fines, costs, and restitution are due during term of supervision.  Court further orders 25% of prison wages to be applied toward Court-ordered financial obligations.  If defendant is released with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment enforceable by all creditors' remedies shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.

**Restitution for all victims to be paid on this case including victims M.K. for $649 and A.Z. for $60 from case 15CF137.

Defendant Mycal R Nealy in court with attorney Matthew E. Weil.  Defendant in custody. Patti l Wabitsch appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Court renders sentence
Sentencing hearing at 08-03-2015 03:00 pm
On request of Atty. Weil, sentencing rescheduled from 8/12/2015 to 8/3/0215 at 3:00 pm. Notice to all parties.
Sentencing hearing at 08-12-2015 03:00 pm

Judge Williams appears in absence of Judge Malloy / Defendant Mycal R Nealy in court with attorney Matthew E. Weil.  Defendant in custody. Patti l Wabitsch appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant enters guilty plea to Ct. 1 & 2 as repeater. Court examines defendant, accepts plea, finds defendant guilty. At time of sentencing, State will recommend on Ct. 1-9 1/2 yrs prison with 5 1/2 years initial confinement and 4 yrs extended supervision, Ct. 2-8 1/2 yrs prison with 5 1/2 initial confinement and 3 1/2 years extended supervision concurrent to Ct. 1. Court is informed the State will be requesting restitution and will not oppose the Earned Release Program for the defendant. On motion of the State, Ct. 3 & 4 dismissed and readin. Court is further informed a probation revocation pending on 14CF95 will be transferred to this court for sentencing.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for August 12, 2015 at 03:00 pm.

Defendant Mycal R Nealy in court with attorney Matthew E. Weil.  Defendant in custody. Adam Yale Gerol appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Officer Lance Wagner sworn and testified.
